author: Laura Hill
title: Newcastle and Northumberland residents hardest hit by council spending cuts
text:
Newcastle and Northumberland residents hardest hit by council spending cuts 15:30, 20 Aug 2016 Figures show council spending per head will fall by almost twice the national average in Newcastle and Northumberland Shares Get daily news by email Newcastle City Council leader Nick Forbes 
Newcastle residents will yet again shoulder some of the worst cuts in council funding, with spending set to fall by nearly £20 per head next year. 
Analysis of government data shows the city will see £19.38 less spent on every man, woman and child in 2017-18 compared to this financial year. 
Only a handful of places - including Blackpool (down £22.03) and Middlesbrough (down £20.10) - will see bigger per-head cuts and the slashes are almost double the national average of £10.66 per head. 
Nick Forbes, leader of Newcastle City Council , said it is unfair that the level of cuts the city is facing is worse than in other areas of the UK. 
Since 2010 the authority has cut spending by £191m, £1,567 per household, and a further £32m will be cut next year. Read More Backlash over plans to cut Durham children's services by £5m - despite quality concerns 
Coun Forbes said: “It is simply unfair that the government continues to cut Newcastle’s budget more deeply than other places. We are working hard to mitigate these cuts, shielding the vulnerable and investing in our city. But this is increasingly difficult as the impact of these cuts over the last six years is being felt right across our city.” 
Northumberland is also in the national top 10, with spending set to drop by £19.56 per head. 
While Sunderland will lose £17.22 per head, County Durham £15.10, South Tyneside £14.45, Redcar and Cleveland £11.79 and Gateshead £9.76. 
Stockton-on-Tees will be down £8.46 per head and North Tyneside just £7.75 per head. Councillor Grant Davey 
Northumberland County Council leader Grant Davey said the rural authority struggles to cope with spending cuts of £58m over the next few years especially when offset against the cost of services in rural areas. 
Coun Davey said: “These figures show a dramatic drop in spending power over the past year and highlights the challenges we face as a rural council. 
“We continue to call on the government to recognise our challenges as it carries out its review into the future of council funding. 
“By 2020 Northumberland will receive £6.85 per head for residents compared to over £66 in metropolitan areas, despite the cost of delivering services in the countryside being three times more costly. Even more astounding is our nearest neighbours in the Scottish Borders due to get £1,400 per head in the next four years.” Read More Northumberland council chiefs criticised for splashing £78m on shopping centre amid cuts 
Durham County Council is on target to have cut spending by a massive £245m between 2011 and 2020, and council leader Simon Henig fears more cuts are to come following Brexit. 
He said: “We continue to face the toughest of times and many significant uncertainties, including the impact of leaving the European Union which is still unknown.”
